G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the District Court’s jurisdictional limit.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the Property is located in Chelsea, Massachusetts, and the acts or omissions giving rise to this Complaint occurred in this jurisdiction.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, tenants are entitled to the quiet enjoyment of their leased premises, pursuant to **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, and consistent with applicable common law principles.

**Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l.raw_text: **Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l Voc. Tech. High Sch. Dist., 461 Mass. 366 (2012)**
**Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l.proposition: A landlord’s failure to address dangerous or hazardous conditions that materially interfere with the safety and habitability of a property constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l.case_name: Town of Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Regional Vocational Technical High School District
**Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with municipal funding obligations for a regional vocational school district and whether a later-enacted Education Reform Act supersedes an earlier special act and regional agreement, plus issues of municipal standing to raise constitutional challenges. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or dangerous or hazardous conditions affecting habitability. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for a rule about a landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Dartmouth v. Greater New Bedford Reg'l.relevant_excerpt: We now consider whether the public school funding obligations imposed on the member municipalities by the Education Reform Act supersede the funding provisions of an agreement among the member municipalities entered into pursuant to St. 1971, c. 428, which authorized the formation of the school district. We also consider whether the member municipalities, as political subdivisions of the Commonwealth, have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the Education Reform Act. For the reasons that follow, we conclude that the complaint filed by Dartmouth and the cross claim filed by Fairhaven were properly dismissed.

**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)*.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered a loss of at least $320 and additional non-economic damages, and Defendant’s breach has caused repeated, ongoing harassment that undermines the quiet enjoyment of her home.
**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)*.support_reasoning: The opinion does support that a landlord’s repeated failure to prevent flooding and sewage intrusions can constitute reckless conduct and statutory interference with quiet enjoyment, causing serious emotional distress. However, it does not mention a specific $320 economic loss figure or any similar quantified minimum loss; the only monetary amounts discussed are rent levels, jury verdicts in the thousands of dollars, and attorneys’ fees. Thus, this case supports the harassment/quiet-enjoyment interference aspect, but not the asserted specific economic loss of at least $320, which makes the cited proposition inaccurate as a whole.
**Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)*.relevant_excerpt: “Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.… In sum, we hold that… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: **Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)**
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Establishing landlord liability for unsafe housing conditions.
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case holds that a public landlord (housing authority) can be liable to tenants for unsafe conditions caused by criminal activity where the landlord fails to take reasonable measures within its control. Although the court rejects a broad duty under the warranty of habitability and nuisance, it expressly recognizes potential landlord liability under G.L. c. 121B, §32D and under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord’s omissions permit dangerous criminal conditions to persist on the premises. That directly supports using the case as authority for landlord liability for unsafe housing conditions (at least under these statutory theories).
**Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.”

**Montanez v. Bagg, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 95.proposition: Illustrates claims regarding tenant quiet enjoyment and personal safety.
**Montanez v. Bagg, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 95.support_reasoning: The opinion certainly involves a landlord–tenant dispute and discusses conditions that endangered or materially impaired the tenants’ health and safety, but the appellate issue and analysis focus on Chapter 93A liability and the willful/knowing standard for multiple damages. The court does not meaningfully analyze the contours of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or personal safety as an independent doctrine; those claims are mentioned only as background to the jury verdict. Thus it is a weak or indirect authority for a proposition specifically about ‘tenant quiet enjoyment and personal safety.’
**Montanez v. Bagg, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 95.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs brought an action… seeking to recover damages and attorney’s fees for: (1) interference with quiet enjoyment and other violations of G. L. c. 186, § 14; (2) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; and (3) violations of G. L. c. 93A, § 2(a)… The evidence warranted the following findings… [that] representatives of the Springfield housing code enforcement department… found numerous violations of the State Sanitary Code which were deemed materially dangerous to the health or safety of occupants… [and] he failed, after notice, to remedy violations of the State Sanitary Code, which endangered or materially impaired their health and safety.

**Lucey v. Hero Int\u2019l Corp., 361 Ma.proposition: Defines breach of quiet enjoyment and appropriate remedies.
**Lucey v. Hero Int\u2019l Corp., 361 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns specific performance of an alleged option to purchase land and focuses on corporate authority and contract indefiniteness. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, what constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment, or remedies for such a breach. Therefore, it cannot be cited as defining breach of quiet enjoyment or the appropriate remedies for that wrong.
**Lucey v. Hero Int\u2019l Corp., 361 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "We are also of the opinion that the option agreement is too indefinite to be specifically enforced. For that additional reason, the final decree is wrong. 'An option to purchase real estate is a unilateral contract by which the owner of the property agrees with the holder of the option that he has the right to buy the property according to the terms and conditions of the contract.' ... 'All the essential terms . . . must be definite and certain so that the intention of the parties may be discovered, the nature and extent of their obligations ascertained, and their rights determined.'"

**Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford,.raw_text: **Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003)**
**Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford,.proposition: Confirms applicability of treble damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
**Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford,.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
**Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford,.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether counterclaims are permitted in commercial summary process actions under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 at all, nor does it address, interpret, or apply treble damages under that statute. Therefore it cannot be cited as confirming the applicability of treble damages under c. 186, § 14.
**Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 239, § 8A, which creates a right to file counterclaims in summary process proceedings, states in pertinent part, “[i]n any action under this chapter to recover possession of any premises rented or leased for dwelling purposes, brought pursuant to a notice to quit for nonpayment of rent . . . the tenant or occupant shall be entitled to raise, by defense or counterclaim, any claim against the plaintiff . . .” (emphasis added). Because a tenant’s right to bring a counterclaim is explicitly limited in § 8A to premises “rented or leased for dwelling purposes,” it is clear that it applies only to summary process actions in residential cases.

**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Recognizes indirect breaches of quiet enjoyment.
**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case squarely recognizes that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment—and thus constructively evict a tenant—through conditions that are not direct acts against the tenant but are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done by another tenant. The court expressly rejects a narrow focus on landlord intent or direct action and imposes liability where the landlord created or allowed a situation (noise from the lounge) and had the right to control it, thereby endorsing an indirect-breach theory of quiet enjoyment.
**Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent….”

**Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Expounds on the landlord’s responsibility to provide a safe environment.
**Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The case is primarily about tenant counterclaims under the warranty of habitability, quiet enjoyment, negligence, retaliation, emotional distress, and G.L. c. 93A, rather than setting out a generalized statement of a landlord’s duty to provide a safe environment. However, in affirming liability for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and negligent failure to maintain the premises, the court necessarily recognizes the landlord’s responsibility to keep the rental premises in a habitable and safe condition (e.g., functioning heat, safe flooring, freedom from vermin). Thus it does support the general proposition, albeit indirectly and in the specific context of Massachusetts habitability and consumer protection law.
**Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; … (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents…. The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects… He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system… and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.”

**Ellis v. Sullivan, 241 Mass. 60 (1922).proposition: Establishes that landlord inaction constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment.
**Ellis v. Sullivan, 241 Mass. 60 (1922).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns rights and obligations in mortgage redemption, interest rates, and equitable accounting between mortgagor, mortgagee, and an inchoate dower holder. It does not discuss landlord‑tenant relations, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or whether landlord inaction can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for that landlord‑tenant proposition.
**Ellis v. Sullivan, 241 Mass. 60 (1922).relevant_excerpt: In the present suit Merton F. Ellis, who is the owner of the equity of redemption in the premises described in said mortgages, seeks an accounting and a decree entitling him to redeem. ... The plaintiff contends that there was error because in order to redeem he must pay interest at the rate of six per cent per annum upon the principal sum secured by the mortgages, instead of the lower rates written in the notes and mortgages.
